results.title: Chinese roulette = Chinesisches roulette
results.creator_credit: Rainer Werner Fassbinder, Albatros and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description: An intense, psychological comedy/drama about a disabled girl, Angela (Andrea Schober), who plots to get herself, both her parents (Alexander Allerson and Margit Cristensen), and their respective lovers (Anna Karina and Ulli Lommel) to the family’s country house all at the same time. The scene is set for a weekend of intense embarassments and confrontations, climaxing in the game of psychological warfare, Chinese Roulette. Typically Fassbinder, the film is a biting attack on the institution of marriage and on middle-class morality. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Fists in the pocket = I pugni in tasca
results.creator_credit: Marco Bellocchio, Enzo Doria and Doria Film
results.brief_description: This bizarre drama chronicles the strange activities of a blind widow living with her four children - Augusto, Sandro, Leone and Giulia. The burden of supporting the family falls on Augusto, the only one of the four not afflicted with epilepsy. When Sandro determines to help Augusto break away and marry his girlfriend, he can see only one way to do it; and sets out to kill the rest of his family. Accompanied by a powerful film score by Ennio Morricone. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Scream 2
results.creator_credit: Wes Craven, Cathy Konrad, Marianne Maddalena and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: The first ‘Scream’ (308434) was a clever genre deconstruction of the do’s and dont’s of the teen slasher film, so it’s not so surprising then that ‘Scream 2’ pays clever homage to sequels. Like all good horror sequels the body count is higher, the murders are more gruesome, but contrary to the belief held by the film literate teens in this film that “sequels suck”, ‘Scream 2’ pleasingly holds its own. It even has it’s own film within a film, “Stab”, the movie version of the events of the first film. This time round, Sydney Prescott (Neve Campbell reprising her role) is at college trying to put the Woodsboro murders behind her, that is until a series of campus murders aping the killings of the first film make it clear that someone is planning a sequel of their own. Director Wes Craven, (no slouch to the genre himself having made ‘Nightmare on Elm St’ and ‘The Hills have Eyes’) and writer Kevin Williamson inject fresh ‘blood’ into the formula by presenting a group of characters to care for (not just a bunch of disposable, horny teens), and by not sacrificing the frights for the sake of a cheap laugh, a common malady of contemporary horror. Cast includes David Arquette, Courtney Cox, Sarah Michelle Gellar, Heather Graham, Jamie Kennedy, Laurie Metcalf, Jerry O’Connell, Liev Schreiber and Jada Pinkett.

results.title: High and low = Tengoku to jigoku [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Ryuzo Kikushima, Tomoyuki Tanaka and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: In the first half a kidnapping takes place and a ransom is negotiated; the second half deals with the manhunt for the kidnapper. The Japanese title - Heaven and Hell - directly suggests exact opposites and more clearly encapsulates the theme. It begins in ‘Heaven’ - the apartment high over the city - and ends in ‘Hell’ - the alleyways of Yokohama. The first half is superficially theatrical in its refusal of conventional editing strategies but actually is notable for its subtle dramatic geometry involving permutations of position and composition afforded by the Scope screen. Multiple cameras were used to film long takes. The film suddenly opens out into an action-packed chase. Based on the novel “King’s Ransom” by Ed McBain. Cast includes Toshiro Mifune, Tatsuya Nakadai, Kyoko Kagawa. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Love is the devil: study for a portrait of Francis Bacon
results.creator_credit: John Maybury, Chiara Menage, BBC Film Unit and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: Love is the Devil: A Study For A Portrait of Francis Bacon is indeed a portrait in the style of controversial British painter Bacon. Like Bacon’s confronting yet compelling portraits, John Maybury’s film intensely focuses on its subject - revelling in distortion and pain. The film follows the turbulent, sado-masochistic relationship Bacon (Derek Jacobi) had with George Dwyer (Daniel Craig), who he meets when he accidently stumbles upon Dwyer attempting to burgle Bacon’s meagre apartment. Francis simply says to George: “Take off your clothes. Come to bed and you can have whatever you want”. The relationship has a destructive effect on the passive George who feels uncomfortable with Bacon’s eccentric friends (Tilda Swinton is especially creepy as one of this coterie), and who is continually tortured by Bacon’s sadistic enjoyment of pain and suffering. Derek Jacobi and Daniel Craig are excellent as the two main characters.

results.title: The Tenderness of wolves = Die Zartlichkeit der Wolfe
results.creator_credit: Ulli Lommel, Rainer Werner Fassbinder and Tango Film Production Number Four
results.brief_description: Based on the life and crimes of Felix Haarmann, the German child murderer who’s killing spree in Dusseldorf during the depression was also the subject of Fritz Lang’s M (1931), and a later version directed by Joseph Losey (1951). Not surprising then that lead actor Kurt Raab, (who also wrote the screenplay and served as art director) pays homage to Peter Lorre in his portrayal of the paedophilic child murderer and sometimes police informer. Produced by Rainer Werner Fassbinder’s production company, (he also makes a brief appearence) ‘The Tenderness of Wolves’, although directed by Ulli Lommel, feels and looks much more like a Fassbinder film and in fact was made during an extended break from “Effie Briest” (1974), which also features Kurt Raab. Ulli Lommel updates the film to post World War Two (mainly due to budget restrictions), and presents the killer as a resourceful, angst- ridden man, who after vampirising the boys would sell their dismembered bodies and clothes on the black market. It’s in Haarmann’s many social connections and the complicity of his friends and police (the tender wolves of the title), that the film draws some of it’s more darker moments. Ultimately, a critique about the society that this monster is allowed to flourish in, ‘The Tenderness of Wolves’ is a disturbing and unsettling experience. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: French cancan
results.creator_credit: Jean Renoir, Louis Wipf and Franco London Film (Paris)
results.brief_description: Beautifully photographed, this comedy-drama chronicles the revival of Paris’ most notorious dance as it tells the story of a theater producer who turns a humble washerwoman into a star at the Moulin Rouge. Renoir’s return to film-making in France after 15 years absence is an exuberant, affectionate homage to the theatre of ‘La Belle Epoque’ (Edith Piaf and Tatachou appear briefly as stars of the day.) It also gave him the opportunity to work with Gabin again, having made three films with him in the 1930s. Cast includes Jean Gabin, Francoise Arnoul and Maria Felix. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: The Silence of the lambs [Portuguese subtitles]
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Demme, Edward Saxon, Kenneth Utt, Ron Bozman, Orion Pictures Corporation and Strongheart Films
results.brief_description: Based on the best-selling novel by Thomas Harris, “Silence of the Lambs” is a disturbing and chilling thriller. The film which won five Academy Awards, is highlighted by the superb performances of Jodie Foster as FBI cadet Clarice Starling and Anthony Hopkins as the psychotic criminal, once brilliant psychiatrist, Dr. Hannibal “the Cannibal” Lecter. Starling’s job is to tap Lector’s mind in order to find the serial killer known as “Buffalo Bill”, a killer who skins his victims. Lector uses his macabre knowledge to entice Clarice into intricate but chilling mindgames. The film’s focal point is not so much the catching of the killer, but the relationship between Starling and Lector. The audience is manipulated so that Lecter is simultaneously repellent and charismatic, thus contributing to the tension and unease of the film. In English with Portugese subtitles.

results.title: Dances with wolves [Portuguese subtitles]
results.creator_credit: Kevin Costner, Jim Wilson, Majestic Films International and TIG Productions
results.brief_description: Assigned to an abandoned army post, Civil War hero John Dunbar (Kevin Costner), finds himself alone and beyond civilisation. Only a wolf and some roving Sioux Indians provide distractions. Curiosity and survival force Dunbar to overcome his fear and he develops a unique relationship with the Sioux. But as the US military ruthlessly pushes west, the Indians’ existence is threatened and Dunbar finds himself torn between two cultures. Honoured with seven Academy Awards including Best Picture (1991), this epic is a cinematic masterpiece of scope, beauty, spirituality and rousing adventure. Dean Semler’s photography is breathtaking. Screenplay by Michael Blake, based on his novel. In English with Portugese subtitles.
